title: China Eximbank suspends debt service payments from Government of Guinea in 2021
description: In response to the COVID-19 pandemic and the G20 Finance Ministers and Central Bank Governors meeting that took place on April 15, 2020 and on November 13, 2020, the Chinese Government agreed to work with other G20 members to implement the Debt Service Suspension Initiative (DSSI). Then, in 2021, China Eximbank and the Government of Guinea signed a debt suspension agreement. Under the terms of the agreement, the lender agreed to suspend principal and interest payments due between January 1, 2021 and June 30, 2021 under one or more loan agreements. The total estimated suspension amount was $8.3 million. However, at the time that the parties signed the debt suspension agreement, they both acknowledged that the total suspension amount would ultimately be determined at the end of the suspension period (since loan disbursements could be made during the suspension period and the lender agreed to suspend the payment of interest accrued on any disbursements during the suspension period). The lender and borrower agreed that the suspension of debt service would be undertaken on a net present value (NPV)-neutral basis. Therefore, the borrower agreed to pay interest accrued on the amount outstanding under the total suspension amount (‘Suspension Interest’) by paying the Suspension Interest on the amount outstanding under each loan agreement’s suspension amount at the same rate of interest set forth in the original loan agreement. The lender and the borrower agreed that the repayment of the suspension amount for each loan agreement would take place in equal, successive, and semi-annual installments during a 5-year repayment period after a 1-year grace period (starting from and including the repayment date/repayment date of principal and interest falling within the suspension period). Additionally, under the terms of the debt suspension agreement, the lender and the borrower agreed that ‘[t]he suspension interest on the amount outstanding under the Suspension Amount concerning each Loan Agreement shall be calculated on the basis of the actual number of days elapsed and a year of 360 days, from and including the Repayment Date/Repayment Date of Principal and Interest falling within the Suspension Period to the date of payment in full of the corresponding Suspension Amount, and shall be paid in arrears on each Interest Payment Date under the corresponding Loan Agreement.’  The borrower also agreed that (1) ‘it shall continue to perform all its obligations […] under the Loan Agreements as supplemented and amended by [the debt suspension agreement]’; (2) ‘it shall use the created fiscal space to increase social, health, or economic spending in response to the COVID-19 crisis […]’ and ‘work closely with the International Financial Institutions who are expected to put in place a monitoring system’;  (3) ‘it shall disclose to the Lender all Public Sector Financial Commitments (as defined in the Government Finance Statistics Manual 2014 (GFSM2014)), respecting commercially sensitive information’; and (4) ‘it shall contract no new non-concessional debt during the Suspension Period, other than agreements under the DSSI’.
staff_comments: 1. AidData assumes that the same basic terms and conditions that governed China Eximbank’s DSSI (debt suspension) agreement with other governments also applied to its DSSI agreement that it signed with the Government of Guinea. Illustrative DSSI agreements can be accessed via https://www.dropbox.com/s/huwa695j3w9hwig/DSSI%20Agreement%20for%20Kyrgyz%20Republic.pdf?dl=0 and https://www.dropbox.com/s/67n1oq44it27kvu/3.%20Debt%20Suspension%20Agreement%20for%20GCL%20Other%20Projects.pdf?dl=0 and https://www.dropbox.com/s/n69i598f0fg7s80/6.%20Debt%20Suspension%20Agreement%20for%20PBC%20C2.pdf?dl=0. 2. The total estimated suspension amount in 2021 ($8.3 million) is based on the amount disclosed in Table 3 of IMF Country Report n° 21/146. This amount is inconsistent with the size of the debt service deferral ($0) that the Government of Guinea secured from the Chinese Government in 2021 (as recorded by the World Bank's Debtor Reporting System on December 6, 2022). This discrepancy warrants further investigation.
combined_text:
# Sector
ACTION RELATING TO DEBT

# Title
China Eximbank suspends debt service payments from Government of Guinea in 2021

# Description
In response to the COVID-19 pandemic and the G20 Finance Ministers and Central Bank Governors meeting that took place on April 15, 2020 and on November 13, 2020, the Chinese Government agreed to work with other G20 members to implement the Debt Service Suspension Initiative (DSSI). Then, in 2021, China Eximbank and the Government of Guinea signed a debt suspension agreement. Under the terms of the agreement, the lender agreed to suspend principal and interest payments due between January 1, 2021 and June 30, 2021 under one or more loan agreements. The total estimated suspension amount was $8.3 million. However, at the time that the parties signed the debt suspension agreement, they both acknowledged that the total suspension amount would ultimately be determined at the end of the suspension period (since loan disbursements could be made during the suspension period and the lender agreed to suspend the payment of interest accrued on any disbursements during the suspension period). The lender and borrower agreed that the suspension of debt service would be undertaken on a net present value (NPV)-neutral basis. Therefore, the borrower agreed to pay interest accrued on the amount outstanding under the total suspension amount (‘Suspension Interest’) by paying the Suspension Interest on the amount outstanding under each loan agreement’s suspension amount at the same rate of interest set forth in the original loan agreement. The lender and the borrower agreed that the repayment of the suspension amount for each loan agreement would take place in equal, successive, and semi-annual installments during a 5-year repayment period after a 1-year grace period (starting from and including the repayment date/repayment date of principal and interest falling within the suspension period). Additionally, under the terms of the debt suspension agreement, the lender and the borrower agreed that ‘[t]he suspension interest on the amount outstanding under the Suspension Amount concerning each Loan Agreement shall be calculated on the basis of the actual number of days elapsed and a year of 360 days, from and including the Repayment Date/Repayment Date of Principal and Interest falling within the Suspension Period to the date of payment in full of the corresponding Suspension Amount, and shall be paid in arrears on each Interest Payment Date under the corresponding Loan Agreement.’  The borrower also agreed that (1) ‘it shall continue to perform all its obligations […] under the Loan Agreements as supplemented and amended by [the debt suspension agreement]’; (2) ‘it shall use the created fiscal space to increase social, health, or economic spending in response to the COVID-19 crisis […]’ and ‘work closely with the International Financial Institutions who are expected to put in place a monitoring system’;  (3) ‘it shall disclose to the Lender all Public Sector Financial Commitments (as defined in the Government Finance Statistics Manual 2014 (GFSM2014)), respecting commercially sensitive information’; and (4) ‘it shall contract no new non-concessional debt during the Suspension Period, other than agreements under the DSSI’.
justification: Debt suspension agreement with no direct environmental or energy transition impact
evidence: Debt service suspension agreement, focus on financial restructuring and COVID-19 response

title: Chinese Embassy awards scholarships to students at Nkrumah Secondary School in May 2021
description: On May 25, 2021, the Chinese Embassy provided the "Chinese Ambassador Scholarship," to students at Nkrumah Secondary School in Guinea-Bissau. The purpose of this donation is to encourage more students to study in China and learn about Chinese culture. The monetary value of each scholarship is unknown.  An award ceremony was held for this donation at the 46th anniversary celebration of Nkrumah Secondary School. At the ceremony, Chinese Ambassador Guo Ce awarded students with the scholarships and delivered a speech. Secretary of State for Teaching and Research Bideta, Principal of Nkrumah Middle School Kasama, and others attended the ceremony.

title: Chinese Government provides 11 vehicles to Guinea-Bissau Ministry of Foreign Affairs in June 2021
description: On June 1, 2021, the Chinese Government provided 11 vehicles to the Guinea-Bissau Ministry for Foreign Affairs & International Cooperation. The purpose of this donation is to support the ministry’s transportation operations. The monetary value of this donation is unknown.  A handover ceremony was held for this donation. China’s Ambassador to Guinea-Bissau Guo Xie and Foreign Minister Barbosa attended the ceremony.

title: Chinese Government provides anti-epidemic supplies to the African Party for the Independence of Guinea and Cape Verde in June 2021
description: On June 8, 2021, the Chinese government donated anti-epidemic supplies to the African Party for the Independence of Guinea and Cape Verde, a political party in Guinea-Bissau. This donation was made to support COVID-19 efforts in Guinea-Bissau. The monetary value of this donation is unknown.  A handover ceremony was held for this donation. Chinese Ambassador Guo Ce and the chairman of the African Party for the Independence of Guinea and Cape Verde attended the ceremony.

title: Chinese Government provides anti-epidemic materials to Guinea-Bissau's Social Revolutionary Party in June 2021
description: On June 16, 2021, the Chinese Government donated anti-epidemic materials to the Social Revolutionary Party of Guinea-Bissau. This donation was made to support the party’s COVID-19 response efforts. The monetary value of this donation is unknown.  A handover ceremony was held for this donation. China’s Ambassador to Guinea-Bissau, Guo Ce, and the party's Vice-President, Dos Santos, attended the ceremony.

title: Chinese Government provides aid materials to Guinea-Bissau National Stadium in November 2021
description: On November 5, 2021, the Chinese Government donated emergency aid materials to Guinea-Bissau's National Stadium. The materials included 80 lighting spotlights for the stadium. This donation was made to provide technical assistance for the stadium and improve the facilities for future international sporting events. The monetary value of this donation is unknown.   A handover ceremony was held for this donation. China’s Ambassador to Guinea-Bissau, Guo Ce, and Guinea-Bissau’s Secretary of State for Youth and Sports Dias attended the ceremony.
combined_text:

This donation was made to provide technical assistance for the stadium and improve the facilities for future international sporting events. The monetary value of this donation is unknown.   A handover ceremony was held for this donation. China’s Ambassador to Guinea-Bissau, Guo Ce, and Guinea-Bissau’s Secretary of State for Youth and Sports Dias attended the ceremony.
justification: Project involves donation of materials for sports infrastructure with no clear environmental or energy transition impact
evidence: Donation of lighting spotlights for national stadium, focus on sports facility improvement

title: Chinese Government provides office materials to the Ministry of Fisheries in Guinea-Bissau in December 2021
description: On December 31, 2021, the Chinese Government provided office materials to the Guinea-Bissau Ministry of Fisheries. The materials will be used to improve the conditions of the office and aid law enforcement activities during the first moratorium. The monetary value of this donation is unknown.  A handover ceremony was held for this donation. Guo Ce, China’s Ambassador to Guinea-Bissau, and the Secretary-General of the Ministry of Fisheries attended the ceremony.

title: Chinese Embassy provides anti-epidemic materials to Mendes Hospital in Guinea-Bissau in June 2021
description: On June 15, 2021, the Chinese Embassy provided anti-epidemic materials to Guinea-Bissau’s Mendes Hospital. The purpose of this donation is to support the hospital’s COVID-19 response. The specific type of materials and monetary value of this donation are unknown.  A handover ceremony was held for this donation.  Li Feng, the Political Counselor of the Chinese Embassy, and the director of Mendes Hospital attended the ceremony.

title: Chinese Embassy provides office supplies to the General Prosecutor's Office of Guinea-Bissau in July 2021

title: Chinese Government provides food aid to Guinea-Bissau through United Nations World Food Program in November 2021
description: On November 17, 2021, the Chinese Government provided food aid to Guinea-Bissau. This donation was made through the United Nations World Food Program at the launching ceremony of China's food aid project to Guinea-Bissau under the South-South Fund. The donation included batches of grain and other food supplies. The donation is intended to alleviate the increased food security problem due to the COVID-19 pandemic. The monetary value of this donation is unknown.   Guo Ce, China’s Ambassador to Guinea-Bissau, the Minister of Education of Guinea-Bissau, and representatives of the United Nations World Food Program in Guinea-Bissau attended the ceremony.
combined_text:
# Sector
DEVELOPMENTAL FOOD AID/FOOD SECURITY ASSISTANCE

# Title
Chinese Government provides food aid to Guinea-Bissau through United Nations World Food Program in November 2021

# Description
On November 17, 2021, the Chinese Government provided food aid to Guinea-Bissau. This donation was made through the United Nations World Food Program at the launching ceremony of China's food aid project to Guinea-Bissau under the South-South Fund. The donation included batches of grain and other food supplies. The donation is intended to alleviate the increased food security problem due to the COVID-19 pandemic. The monetary value of this donation is unknown.   Guo Ce, China’s Ambassador to Guinea-Bissau, the Minister of Education of Guinea-Bissau, and representatives of the United Nations World Food Program in Guinea-Bissau attended the ceremony.
justification: Project is focused on food aid and security assistance without direct environmental or energy transition impacts
evidence: Food aid donation through UN World Food Program, focus on alleviating food security issues
